title: The 2-Minute Launch
prompt: You don't have to finish it. You just have to start.
instructions: Pick one task you've been avoiding. Set a timer for 2 minutes. Do only that task for 2 minutes — when the timer goes off, you're done (or keep going if you want). The rule is: you ONLY have to do 2 minutes.
success_criteria: You started the task. That's the win. Even 10 seconds counts.

title: The Ready-Set-Go
prompt: Getting started is the hardest part. Let's trick your brain into it.
instructions: Think of one thing you need to do today. Say out loud (or write): "I will do [task] at [time] for [X] minutes." Then at that time, stand up and say "Ready... Set... Go!" before you begin.
success_criteria: You said the words AND started within 60 seconds of your set time.

title: The 3-Step Shrink
prompt: Big tasks feel huge because we see them as one giant blob. Let's shrink it.
instructions: Choose one task that feels overwhelming. Break it into exactly 3 smaller steps — no more. Write each step as an action starting with a verb (e.g., "Open the document", "Write the first sentence", "Save and close"). Now do Step 1 only.
success_criteria: You have 3 written action steps and completed Step 1.

title: The Weekly Anchor
prompt: Having 3 non-negotiables per week beats having 20 forgotten tasks.
instructions: Write down 3 things that, if you did ONLY these this week, you'd feel genuinely good about. Not a full to-do list — just 3. Rank them 1-2-3 by importance. Put them somewhere visible.
success_criteria: You have 3 written anchors for the week, ranked and visible.
tags: weekly planning, priorities, adult, executive function

title: The Triage Sort
prompt: Your brain wants to do everything at once. This drill forces a decision.
instructions: Write down everything on your mind right now (tasks, worries, ideas) — spend 3 minutes dumping it all out. Then mark each item: A (urgent + important), B (important, not urgent), C (everything else). Circle your one A item. That's your next move.
success_criteria: You have a brain dump list with at least one item categorised and one A item circled.

title: The 3-Pile Sort
prompt: When everything feels important, nothing gets done. Let's sort it out.
instructions: Write or draw the things you need to do this week on separate sticky notes or slips of paper. Sort them into 3 piles: TODAY, SOON, and LATER. Pick the top item from TODAY. Do that next.
success_criteria: You sorted your tasks into piles and identified one "do next" task.

title: The 10-Minute Reset
prompt: Chaos drains energy. Order creates calm — even small order.
instructions: Set a timer for 10 minutes. Pick one small space (desk, bag, drawer, shelf). Put things back where they belong. Throw away what's rubbish. Stop when the timer goes off — even if it's not perfect.
success_criteria: You spent 10 minutes on the reset. The space is measurably tidier than before.

title: The Backpack Scan
prompt: A chaotic bag creates a chaotic morning. 5 minutes fixes it.
instructions: Empty your school bag completely. Sort items into: NEED FOR TOMORROW, PUT AWAY, and BIN. Repack only what you need. Check that homework is in there.
success_criteria: Bag is repacked with only needed items. Homework is inside.

title: The Time Estimator
prompt: ADHD often distorts how long things actually take. Let's recalibrate.
instructions: Choose 3 upcoming tasks. Before doing them, write down how long you THINK each will take. Then actually do them and record the real time. Compare your estimates to reality. Were you over or under?
success_criteria: You completed the exercise and recorded both estimated and actual times for at least 2 tasks.

title: The Clock Challenge
prompt: Can you guess how long things take? Most people with ADHD are surprised.
instructions: Pick 3 things you do every day (getting dressed, eating breakfast, packing bag). Guess how long each takes, then time yourself doing each one. Were your guesses right?
success_criteria: You timed yourself on at least 2 tasks and compared to your guess.
tags: time blindness, youth, daily routine, awareness

title: The Reverse Timeline
prompt: Working backward from a deadline makes the invisible visible.
instructions: Think of a project or goal with a deadline. Write the deadline at the top of a page. Work BACKWARDS: what must happen the day before? The week before? The month before? Fill in reverse until you reach today.
success_criteria: You have a written reverse timeline with at least 4 milestones mapped to dates.

title: The Mission Map
prompt: Every goal is like a level in a game. Map yours out.
instructions: Pick a goal (could be a school project, a sport, learning something). Draw a simple map or ladder with your goal at the top. Fill in 4-5 "steps" or "levels" you need to climb to get there. Number them. What's Level 1?
success_criteria: You have a visual map with at least 4 steps drawn and Level 1 identified.

title: The Transition Countdown
prompt: Switching tasks is hard. A countdown makes the brain feel safe.
instructions: When you need to switch from one activity to another, give yourself a 5-minute countdown warning. Say or think: "In 5 minutes I'm switching to [next task]." At 2 minutes, say it again. Then close down what you're doing before starting new.
success_criteria: You used the countdown transition at least once today and switched without a major conflict or meltdown.

title: The Closing Ritual
prompt: Finishing one thing properly helps your brain move to the next.
instructions: When you finish school, homework, or a game, do this 3-step closing ritual: (1) Put things away, (2) Say "Done!" out loud, (3) Take 3 deep breaths. This tells your brain: that chapter is closed.
success_criteria: You completed the 3-step closing ritual at least once today.

title: The Grocery List Game
prompt: Working memory is like RAM — you can train it to hold more.
instructions: Ask someone to read you a list of 5 random items (or generate one). Try to repeat them back in order without writing anything down. Each day, increase by one item. Track your personal best.
success_criteria: You correctly recalled the list — or beat your previous record.
tags: recall, verbal memory, daily drill, progressive

title: The Word Chain
prompt: Keep the chain alive — without breaking it.
instructions: Start with any word (e.g., "apple"). The next word must start with the last letter of the previous word (apple → elephant → tiger...). Play solo or with someone. Try to keep the chain going for 2 minutes without repeating.
success_criteria: You kept the chain going for at least 90 seconds without repeating a word.

title: Digit Span Forward
prompt: Your brain can hold about 7 digits at a time. Let's test yours.
instructions: Read (or have someone read) a string of numbers, starting at 4 digits. Repeat them back in order. Add one digit each round. Stop when you fail twice at the same length. Record your span.
success_criteria: You identified your current digit span and recorded it.
materials_needed: none or a list of number strings

title: Digit Span Backward
prompt: A harder version: repeat the numbers in REVERSE order.
instructions: Same as Digit Span Forward — but this time, repeat the numbers BACKWARDS. Start at 3 digits. Add one digit each round. Stop when you fail twice. This tests active manipulation of memory, not just storage.
success_criteria: You identified your backward digit span.
tags: working memory, adult, reverse, cognitive load

title: The Object Snapshot
prompt: Train your visual memory with everyday objects.
instructions: Place 8 random objects on a table. Study them for 60 seconds. Cover them with a cloth or leave the room. Write down as many as you can remember. Check. Increase to 10 objects tomorrow.
success_criteria: You recalled at least 5 of 8 objects correctly.
materials_needed: household objects, cloth or paper to cover them

title: The Tray Game
prompt: How much can your eyes actually hold?
instructions: Put 6 items on a tray. Look at them for 30 seconds. Cover the tray. Draw or list what you saw. Check! Add more items each round. Can you beat your score?
success_criteria: You correctly identified at least 4 out of 6 items.
materials_needed: tray, household objects, paper to cover

title: The Running Total
prompt: Keep a tally in your head — no writing allowed.
instructions: Listen to (or read) a sequence of numbers being added one at a time. Start at 0. Add each new number in your head. Report the total at the end. Start with 5 numbers, increase to 10.
success_criteria: You correctly calculated the running total or came within 5% of it.
materials_needed: number sequence (prepared list or use dice)
tags: arithmetic, mental maths, working memory, calculation

title: The Mission Briefing
prompt: Can you remember all the instructions without peeking?
instructions: Ask someone to give you a 3-step instruction (e.g., "Go to the kitchen, fill a glass of water, and put it on the table"). Complete all 3 steps from memory — no reminders. Add one step each round.
success_criteria: You completed all steps in the correct order without prompting.

title: The Dual Track
prompt: Working memory under pressure — multitasking training.
instructions: Set a timer for 2 minutes. Count backwards from 100 by 3s (100, 97, 94...) while simultaneously writing a list of 10 items in a category (e.g., countries, fruits). Stop at 2 minutes. Check your counting AND your list.
success_criteria: You counted at least 10 steps correctly AND wrote at least 6 items.
tags: dual task, adult, cognitive load, simultaneous

title: The Story Snapshot
prompt: Narrative memory is a powerful everyday tool.
instructions: Read or listen to a short paragraph (news story, Wikipedia excerpt, or book passage — 100-150 words). Put it away. Write down the 5 most important facts you remember. Check accuracy against the source.
success_criteria: You correctly recalled at least 3 of the 5 most important facts.

title: The Map From Memory
prompt: Spatial working memory helps with navigation and planning.
instructions: Study a simple map (room layout, campus, local area) for 2 minutes. Put it away. Redraw it from memory. Label as many features as you can. Compare to the original.
success_criteria: Your redrawn map contains at least 60% of the key features.

title: The Mind's Eye Sculptor
prompt: Train your brain to build and hold pictures.
instructions: Close your eyes. Picture a simple object (a red apple). Now rotate it in your mind. Now change the colour to blue. Add a bite taken out of it. Now place it on a wooden table. Open your eyes and draw what you imagined.
success_criteria: You drew a picture that matches the sequence of mental transformations.

title: The Pomodoro Starter
prompt: 5 minutes of pure focus — no switching, no distracting.
instructions: Set a timer for 5 minutes. Choose ONE task. Do only that. If your mind wanders, gently bring it back — no judgment. When the timer ends, mark a tally. Each day try to complete 2 of these. Work up to 25 minutes over weeks.
success_criteria: You completed the full 5 minutes on one task with the timer running.

title: The Finish Line Challenge
prompt: Can you stay in the zone for 10 whole minutes?
instructions: Pick something you need to do (homework, reading, drawing). Set a timer for 10 minutes. Every time your mind wanders, make a small mark on a piece of paper — but keep going. Count your marks at the end. Try to reduce the count each day.
success_criteria: You worked for the full 10 minutes and tracked your mind-wanders.

title: The Deep Work Block
prompt: 25 minutes of unbroken concentration. Phone away. Browser closed.
instructions: Before starting: write ONE task you'll work on. Put your phone face-down across the room. Close all browser tabs except what's needed. Set a 25-minute timer. Work. If an intrusive thought appears, write it in a "parking lot" notebook and return to task immediately.
success_criteria: You completed 25 minutes without checking your phone or switching tasks. Parking lot has any wandering thoughts captured.
tags: deep work, adult, single task, phone-free

title: The Noisy Reading Test
prompt: Train your brain to filter out distractions.
instructions: Put on background noise (TV in another room, café sounds, music with lyrics). Read a page of a book or article for 5 minutes. Then close it and write 3 key ideas from what you read.
success_criteria: You correctly identified at least 2 key ideas from the reading despite noise.

title: The Boring Task Buster
prompt: ADHD brains rebel against boring. This drill builds tolerance.
instructions: Pick the most boring thing on your task list. Set a timer for 15 minutes. Do ONLY that boring task. Notice your urge to escape — but stay. Reward yourself with 5 minutes of something enjoyable immediately after.
success_criteria: You stayed with the boring task for the full 15 minutes.

title: The Stick-With-It Star
prompt: Even when it's hard or boring — you can do it.
instructions: Pick something you don't really want to do (cleaning, a hard bit of homework). Set a timer for 10 minutes. Stick with it even when it's dull. Put a star on a chart when you complete it. Collect 5 stars this week.
success_criteria: Timer completed. Star added to chart.
tags: youth, persistence, reward chart, boring tasks

title: The Reset Drill
prompt: When focus breaks, it's not failure — it's an opportunity to practice returning.
instructions: Work on a task for 15 minutes. When you notice your attention has drifted (and it will), say "Reset" and name: (1) where you are, (2) what you were doing, (3) what sentence or step you were on. Then continue. Count resets.
success_criteria: You recovered from at least 3 attention drifts using the Reset protocol.

title: The Flow Ritual
prompt: Flow states are accessible — they need a consistent on-ramp.
instructions: Before starting a 30-minute work block, complete this ritual: (1) Clear your workspace, (2) Write the specific output you want to produce, (3) Put on the same music/sounds you always use for focus, (4) Take 3 slow breaths, (5) Read your task description aloud. Then begin.
success_criteria: You completed the ritual AND worked for at least 20 of 30 minutes on the single task.
materials_needed: timer, consistent focus music, cleared workspace
tags: flow state, ritual, adult, deep work

title: The Focus Zone Setup
prompt: Your environment either helps or fights your focus. Design it.
instructions: Draw or describe your current workspace. Now redesign it for focus: (1) Remove visible distractions, (2) Put the one thing you need to do front and centre, (3) Add one comfort item (water, plant, good light). Then physically make these changes.
success_criteria: You made at least 2 physical changes to your environment.

title: The Phone Quarantine
prompt: The phone is the #1 focus killer. This drill builds control over it.
instructions: For the next hour, put your phone in another room (not in your pocket or face-down on your desk). Complete one task during that hour. After the hour, check your phone. Note: Did you survive? Did the work improve?
success_criteria: Phone was in a separate room for the full hour. One task was completed.

title: The Reading Dive
prompt: Read without pictures or videos for 10 whole minutes.
instructions: Choose a book, magazine, or article that you're even a little bit interested in. Set a timer for 10 minutes. Read without stopping. If your brain drifts, put your finger on the word you were on and come back.
success_criteria: You read for 10 consecutive minutes and can say what the section was about.

title: The Active Listening Drill
prompt: Most of us hear words but don't process them. Let's change that.
instructions: Listen to a podcast, audio story, or spoken explanation for 5 minutes without doing anything else. No phone, no doodling. Afterwards, write 3 things you remember. Check by re-listening if possible.
success_criteria: You recalled at least 2 of 3 key points without re-listening.

title: The 5-Second Pause
prompt: Between impulse and action, there is a gap. This drill widens it.
instructions: Every time today that you feel an urge to do something impulsive (interrupt, click away, send a message, eat something you didn't plan to), pause and count silently to 5 before acting. Tally how many times you used the pause. No judgment if you don't manage every one.
success_criteria: You used the 5-second pause at least 3 times today.

title: The Traffic Light
prompt: Red = Stop. Yellow = Think. Green = Go.
instructions: When you feel like doing something impulsive (shouting out, grabbing, running off), picture a traffic light in your head. RED: Stop your body. YELLOW: Ask yourself "what will happen if I do this?" GREEN: Make a better choice. Practise this 3 times today.
success_criteria: You used the traffic light method at least 3 times today.

title: The Urge Surf
prompt: Urges peak and fade like waves. You can ride them without wiping out.
instructions: When an urge hits (to check your phone, eat, procrastinate), set a timer for 10 minutes and do something else. Notice: Does the urge fade? Get stronger? Change? Write a 2-sentence observation afterward.
success_criteria: Timer completed. 2-sentence observation written.

title: The Wait Game
prompt: Waiting is a superpower. And you can practice it.
instructions: Choose a reward you want (screen time, a snack, a game). Before getting it, set a timer for 10 minutes and do one small productive task first. When the timer goes off, enjoy your reward. Track how many times you played the Wait Game this week.
success_criteria: Timer completed and productive task done before reward. Tracked in log.

title: The Listening Hold
prompt: Interrupting others is one of the most common ADHD patterns. This trains the hold.
instructions: In your next conversation (or in class), keep a small notepad with you. Every time you have an urge to interrupt, write your thought down instead. Wait. After the person finishes, decide if your note is still worth saying.
success_criteria: You wrote down at least 2 "held" thoughts instead of interrupting.

title: The Slow Reply Rule
prompt: Reactive messages damage relationships. This drill builds a gap.
instructions: Today, for any non-urgent message, email, or comment you receive, wait at least 15 minutes before replying. During that time, write your first-draft emotional reaction — then write what you actually want to say. Send the second version.
success_criteria: At least one reply was delayed 15 minutes and reviewed before sending.

title: The 24-Hour Cart
prompt: Impulsive spending is an ADHD tax. This drill intercepts it.
instructions: Any non-essential purchase you feel an urge to make: add it to a cart or wish list, but do NOT buy it for 24 hours. After 24 hours, revisit the list. Cross off anything you no longer want. Only buy what remains AND was planned.
success_criteria: You waited 24 hours before any impulse purchase. At least one item was crossed off.

title: The Consequence Scan
prompt: Impulsive decisions feel great for 10 seconds and bad for 10 days.
instructions: Think of a recent decision you made impulsively. Write: (1) What was the impulse, (2) What did you do, (3) What happened as a result, (4) What would you do differently? No self-blame — just analysis.
success_criteria: All 4 prompts answered in writing.

title: The One-More Buster
prompt: One more video is the most expensive phrase for ADHD brains.
instructions: Before starting any screen-based entertainment, set a timer AND write down the stop time. When the timer goes off, actually stop. Do not negotiate. Close the screen immediately.
success_criteria: You stopped screen time when the timer went off on at least 2 occasions today.

title: The Brain-to-Mouth Filter
prompt: Train your brain to check thoughts before they become words.
instructions: Before saying something today — especially something that pops into your head — ask yourself: Is it true? Is it kind? Does it need to be said? If YES to all three, say it. If NO to any, hold it or reframe it.
success_criteria: You used the filter at least 3 times today. Note one example in your journal.

title: The Deliberate Choice Drill
prompt: Act deliberately, not automatically.
instructions: For 10 minutes, narrate EVERY action you take in your head (e.g., "I am choosing to stand up. I am choosing to open this drawer. I am choosing to sit back down."). This forces the brain's deliberate system to engage.
success_criteria: You narrated your actions for 10 full minutes without breaking the narration.

title: The Space Bar
prompt: In conflict, the first response is rarely the best one.
instructions: Think of a recent argument or conflict. Write a timeline: (1) Trigger, (2) Your first impulse response, (3) What you actually said/did, (4) Ideal response with hindsight. Look for patterns. Where's your personal "hot spot"?
success_criteria: All 4 elements written. One personal pattern identified.

title: The 5-4-3-2-1 Ground
prompt: When emotions spiral, the senses pull you back to now.
instructions: When feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or shut down: name 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste. Say them out loud or write them. Notice your nervous system settle.
success_criteria: You completed the full sequence and felt a measurable shift in calm.

title: The Body Scan Pause
prompt: Your body knows your feelings before your brain does.
instructions: Sit comfortably. Close your eyes. Start at your feet and slowly notice: are your legs tense? Your stomach? Your chest? Your jaw? Name what you feel — tense, loose, warm, cold, fast, slow. No need to fix anything. Just notice.
success_criteria: You completed a full body scan from feet to head.

title: The Feelings Label
prompt: Naming an emotion reduces its power over you by up to 50% (neuroscience fact).
instructions: At the end of today, write 3 emotions you felt and what triggered each one. Use specific feeling words (not just "bad" or "good"). Try: frustrated, embarrassed, excited, proud, anxious, disappointed, hopeful, defeated, curious.
success_criteria: You identified and named 3 distinct emotions with triggers. No vague words like "fine" or "okay".

title: My Feelings Map
prompt: Feelings have shapes, colours, and sizes. What do yours look like?
instructions: Draw a simple outline of a body. Colour in where you feel different emotions today (e.g., red for angry in your chest, yellow for happy in your face, blue for sad in your throat). Label each colour with the feeling.
success_criteria: Body map drawn with at least 3 emotions located and labelled.

title: The Frustration Ladder
prompt: Frustration is a ladder — catching it early means a shorter fall.
instructions: Today, when you notice frustration rising, rate it 1-10 and write it down. At a 3, use breathing. At a 5, take a 2-minute walk. At a 7, leave the room before reacting. Track where you caught it each time.
success_criteria: You caught frustration at least once and used a level-appropriate strategy.

title: The Cool-Down Kit
prompt: When feelings get too big, you need a kit that helps you cool down.
instructions: Create a "Cool-Down Kit" — 3 things that help you calm down when you're upset (e.g., squeeze a stress ball, listen to a song, do 10 jumping jacks, draw something). Write or draw the kit. Use it the next time feelings get big.
success_criteria: Kit is written or drawn with at least 3 strategies. Used at least once this week.
materials_needed: notebook or card, any chosen items

title: The Rejection Reframe
prompt: ADHD often comes with Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD). This is a tool to work with it.
instructions: Think of a recent moment when you felt strongly rejected or criticised. Write: (1) What happened, (2) What story you told yourself about it, (3) What evidence supports AND challenges that story, (4) A more balanced view. The goal is accuracy, not toxic positivity.
success_criteria: All 4 elements completed. A balanced alternative statement is written.

title: The Bounce-Back Story
prompt: Everyone fails and feels bad sometimes. What matters is what happens next.
instructions: Think of a time things went wrong and you felt really bad. Write or draw: (1) What happened, (2) How you felt, (3) What you did next, (4) What you learned. Notice: you survived it. That makes you stronger.
success_criteria: All 4 parts are written or drawn. One thing learned is identified.

title: The Mood Log
prompt: Patterns in your mood are data. Data gives you power.
instructions: For 7 days, fill in a simple log at the same time each day: Time, Mood (1-10), Energy (1-10), What you ate last, Sleep hours last night. After 7 days, look for patterns. Are there predictable lows? Highs?
success_criteria: 7 days of completed logs with at least one pattern identified.

title: The Kind Inner Voice
prompt: ADHD often comes with a brutal inner critic. This drill offers an alternative.
instructions: Write down 3 harsh things your inner critic says to you regularly. For each one, write what a kind, wise friend would say instead. Read the kind versions aloud. Notice how your body responds.
success_criteria: 3 harsh thoughts rewritten as compassionate alternatives. Read aloud.

title: The Kind Words Letter
prompt: You deserve kindness — especially from yourself.
instructions: Write a short letter to yourself from your best friend's point of view. They know you really well and they like you. What would they say about your good qualities? What would they encourage you about? Write at least 5 sentences.
success_criteria: Letter written with at least 5 sentences and at least 3 positive qualities mentioned.

title: The Worry Slot
prompt: Giving anxiety a scheduled time takes its power away the rest of the day.
instructions: Choose one 10-minute worry slot per day (same time each day). When a worry appears outside that slot, write it on a list and tell yourself: "I'll think about that at [time]." At the slot, open the list and think about each one. Many will have resolved.
success_criteria: Worry slot completed. At least 2 worries were moved to the list instead of ruminated on during the day.

title: The Daily Win Log
prompt: ADHD brains filter OUT successes and filter IN failures. Reverse the filter.
instructions: Every evening, write 3 things that went well today — no matter how small. "I remembered to eat lunch" counts. "I responded to one message" counts. The size of the win doesn't matter. The noticing does.
success_criteria: Three wins written, no matter how small.

title: The Morning Anchor Routine
prompt: A good morning shapes a good day. Build one anchor you can always do.
instructions: Design a 3-step morning anchor: one thing for your body (e.g., drink water, stretch), one for your mind (e.g., read today's tasks), one for your mood (e.g., music, fresh air). Write it down. Do it for 7 days in a row.
success_criteria: Routine designed and completed for at least 5 out of 7 days.

title: The Morning Launchpad
prompt: A smooth morning starts the night before AND the morning of.
instructions: Create a "Launchpad Checklist" for your morning (e.g., eat breakfast, get dressed, pack bag, check timetable). Put it on your bedroom door. Tick it off each morning. Try for 5 days in a row.
success_criteria: Checklist made and used for at least 3 consecutive mornings.

title: The Active Recall Study Session
prompt: Re-reading is passive. This technique actually wires in the learning.
instructions: Read a section of your notes or textbook for 5 minutes. Close it. Write everything you can remember. Open it. Check what you missed. Reread missed items. Repeat. This is 3x more effective than just re-reading.
success_criteria: You completed at least 2 active recall rounds on the same material.
materials_needed: textbook or notes, blank paper, timer

title: The Teach-Back Method
prompt: If you can explain it, you understand it. Pretend you're the teacher.
instructions: After studying a topic, pretend you are explaining it to a younger student. Say it out loud or write it in simple words. Don't look at your notes. When you get stuck, that's what you still need to learn.
success_criteria: You explained the topic without notes for at least 2 minutes and identified at least one gap in your understanding.
materials_needed: notes to study first, no notes during teach-back

title: The MIT Method
prompt: Most Important Task first — before the day hijacks you.
instructions: Before starting work each day, write your 3 Most Important Tasks (MITs). These should take 20-90 minutes each. Do MIT #1 before opening email or any messaging. Block the time in your calendar.
success_criteria: 3 MITs written before starting work. MIT #1 started before email was opened.

title: The End-of-Day Handoff
prompt: Ending the workday with intention prevents the bleed-over that exhausts ADHD brains.
instructions: At the end of each work day, spend 5 minutes: (1) Write what you completed, (2) Write your top 3 MITs for tomorrow, (3) Close all tabs and apps. This creates a clear psychological boundary.
success_criteria: End-of-day routine completed. Tomorrow's 3 MITs are written.

title: The One-Touch Rule
prompt: The pile is made of good intentions. One-touch stops the pile.
instructions: The rule: whenever you handle an item (mail, a dish, a piece of clothing), deal with it fully right then — put it away, bin it, or file it. Do not put it down to handle later. Practice this for one category of item today (e.g., post/mail only).
success_criteria: You applied the one-touch rule to at least 5 items today.

title: The Name Anchor
prompt: Remembering names shows people they matter. ADHD makes this hard. Here's a fix.
instructions: When you meet someone new, say their name back within the first 30 seconds: "Great to meet you, [Name]." Then use it once more in the conversation. Afterwards, write the name with one detail about them.
success_criteria: You used the person's name twice during the conversation and recorded it with a memory hook.

title: The Money Snapshot
prompt: You can't manage what you don't see. This drill creates clarity.
instructions: Spend 20 minutes writing down every regular monthly expense you can think of. Categorise: Fixed (rent, bills), Variable (food, transport), Optional (subscriptions, eating out). Total each category. Is this what you expected?
success_criteria: All 3 categories listed with totals. One surprising item identified.

title: The Buffer Builder
prompt: ADHD underestimates travel time, prep time, and transition time. Add a buffer.
instructions: Look at your schedule for tomorrow. For each commitment, add 15 minutes before it as buffer time. Block this buffer in your calendar or planner. Treat it as sacred — not for squeezing in other tasks.
success_criteria: Tomorrow's schedule has 15-minute buffers before each commitment, blocked in writing.

title: The Connection Check-In
prompt: ADHD can create distance in relationships without meaning to. This drill closes the gap.
instructions: Think of the 3 most important relationships in your life. For each one, ask: When did I last reach out proactively? When did I last really listen? What do they need from me right now? Write one action you'll take for each relationship this week.
success_criteria: 3 relationships assessed. One action per relationship written.

title: The Sleep Countdown
prompt: Sleep is the foundation of ADHD management. Build a wind-down signal.
instructions: 30 minutes before your planned sleep time: screens off, lights dimmer, no new stimulating content. Do one calm activity (reading fiction, light stretching, drawing, listening to calm music). Track how long it takes to fall asleep each night for 5 nights.
success_criteria: Screens off 30 minutes before bed for at least 4 of 5 nights. Sleep onset time tracked.

title: The WOOP Goal Frame
prompt: Wishing alone doesn't work. This science-backed method does.
instructions: For one goal, write: W = Wish (what you want), O = Outcome (how it will feel when achieved), O = Obstacle (what will most likely get in the way — be honest), P = Plan (if [obstacle] happens, then I will [specific action]). Complete all 4.
success_criteria: All 4 WOOP elements written clearly. The obstacle and plan sections are specific (not vague).

title: The Monthly Review
prompt: Looking back builds awareness. Looking forward builds direction.
instructions: At the end of every month, write answers to: (1) What 3 things went well this month? (2) What one thing didn't go as planned? (3) What did I learn about myself? (4) What's my one focus for next month?
success_criteria: All 4 questions answered. One focus for next month written.

title: The ADHD Disclosure Script
prompt: Knowing how to explain your ADHD to others is a life skill.
instructions: Write a 3-4 sentence personal script that explains your ADHD honestly and practically to a new manager, teacher, or partner. Focus on: what works for you, what you need, and what you bring to the table. Practice saying it aloud.
success_criteria: Script written. Said aloud at least twice with a confident tone.

title: The In/Out List
prompt: Before you plan HOW to do a task, you need to know exactly WHAT the task is — and what it isn't.
instructions: Take a task you need to do. Draw a line down a page. On the left write IN: everything that IS part of this task. On the right write OUT: everything that is NOT your job, or doesn't need doing to call this task complete. Most people skip this step — and that's why tasks expand endlessly.
success_criteria: You have a written IN and OUT list for one task. The OUT column has at least 2 entries.

title: The Done Line
prompt: Tasks feel endless when you don't know what "finished" actually looks like. Fix that first.
instructions: Before starting any task, write one sentence that completes this phrase: "This task is done when..." Be specific. Not "when it's tidy" but "when every item has a place and the floor is clear." Not "when the essay is written" but "when the essay is 500 words, spell-checked, and saved."
success_criteria: You wrote a specific, testable "done" statement for one task before starting it.

title: The Finish Line Description
prompt: If you don't know what the finish line looks like, how will you know when you've crossed it?
instructions: Pick one task (homework, a chore, a project). Write or draw what it will look like when it's truly finished. Be specific — what can you see, check, hand in, or tick off? Now read it back. Does it feel clear? If not, make it sharper.
success_criteria: A specific, visual "finished" description is written or drawn.

title: The Task Dissection
prompt: Every task is actually several smaller tasks wearing a disguise. Expose them.
instructions: Choose one task. Ask: "What are ALL the separate actions required to complete this?" Write each action as a verb + object (e.g., "Find the form", "Fill in Section 2", "Attach the receipt", "Email to accounts"). Include the boring prep steps most people forget (finding materials, printing, travel time).
success_criteria: You have a task broken into at least 5 specific verb-led actions, including at least one prep step.
tags: decomposition, action steps, task anatomy, planning

title: The Recipe Plan
prompt: Every task is like a recipe — it has ingredients, steps, and a finished dish.
instructions: Pick a task (like making a poster, writing a story, or tidying a space). Write it out like a recipe: INGREDIENTS (what you need), STEPS (in order — number them), and FINISHED DISH (what it looks like when done). Now look at Step 1. Can you start right now?
success_criteria: Recipe plan written with all 3 sections. Step 1 is clear and immediately actionable.
tags: youth, recipe, task steps, visual, planning

title: The "Before This" Chain
prompt: Some steps are blocked until other things happen. Finding those blockers early prevents last-minute chaos.
instructions: Take your task's action list (or create one now). For each step, ask: "Is there anything that must happen BEFORE this?" Draw an arrow from the blocker to the step it unlocks. Highlight any steps that nothing else can start until they're done — those are your start-first priorities.
success_criteria: You identified at least 2 dependency relationships in your task. One "must start first" step is circled or highlighted.

title: The Can't-Do-Yet List
prompt: Some steps in a plan are stuck behind other steps. Finding that out early saves a lot of frustration.
instructions: Write out the steps of a task or project. For each step, ask: "Can I do this right now, or does something else need to happen first?" Sort them into two columns: CAN DO NOW and STUCK BEHIND (name what's blocking it). Start on the CAN DO NOW list immediately.
success_criteria: Two-column sort completed. At least one blocker is named. CAN DO NOW list has at least 2 items.

title: The What-Do-I-Need Scan
prompt: Starting a task and then discovering you're missing something halfway through is an ADHD focus-killer.
instructions: Before starting a task, ask: "What do I need to complete this?" Write two lists: THINGS (physical materials, tools, files, logins) and PEOPLE (anyone whose input, permission, or help you need). Get everything on those lists in place BEFORE you start.
success_criteria: Both lists written. You have confirmed at least one item is actually available before starting.

title: The Kit Check
prompt: Nothing breaks focus faster than realising mid-task that you don't have what you need.
instructions: Before you begin any task or activity, do a Kit Check: write down everything you'll need. Then go get each item and place it in front of you. Only start when the kit is assembled. This 3-minute habit saves 15 minutes of broken focus later.
success_criteria: Kit Check list written and all items physically gathered before starting.

title: The Time Budget
prompt: Planning without time estimates is like shopping without money — you'll overspend and run out.
instructions: Take your task's action list. For each step, write a realistic time estimate. Add them up. Does the total fit in your available time today? If not, decide: which steps can move to tomorrow? Which can be shortened? Adjust until the plan is realistic.
success_criteria: Every action step has a time estimate. The total is calculated. Plan is adjusted to fit available time.

title: The Guess-Then-Check
prompt: How long will your tasks actually take? Most people have no idea. Here's how to find out.
instructions: Before doing your homework or tasks today, write each one down and guess how long it'll take. Then do them and write the actual time. Compare. Were you over or under? Over time, your guesses will get more accurate — and your planning will get much better.
success_criteria: At least 3 tasks estimated and timed. Estimated vs actual recorded and compared.

title: The Daily Blueprint
prompt: Five minutes of planning saves an hour of confusion. Build this habit every morning.
instructions: Each morning, before anything else, write: (1) The ONE outcome that would make today a success, (2) Three tasks that move toward that outcome, (3) Any fixed commitments (meetings, appointments), (4) One realistic buffer for the unexpected. That's your blueprint. Refer back to it during the day.
success_criteria: Blueprint written with all 4 sections before starting work or school.

title: The Today Map
prompt: Map out your day before it maps you.
instructions: Each morning, draw a simple timeline for your day (you can use boxes or columns). Fill in: things that are fixed (school, meals, lessons), things you need to do (homework, chores), and one thing you want to do. Look at the gaps — that's your free planning time. Is there enough time for everything?
success_criteria: Today Map drawn with fixed, need-to-do, and want-to-do sections filled in.

title: The Sunday Blueprint
prompt: The week you plan is the week you control. The week you don't plan controls you.
instructions: Every Sunday (or your week's start), spend 20 minutes: (1) Review last week — what didn't get done? (2) List all commitments this week, (3) Assign your 3 most important tasks to specific days and times, (4) Identify one likely obstacle and write your response plan for it.
success_criteria: All 4 sections completed. At least 3 tasks are assigned to specific days.

title: The Week Planner
prompt: When you know what's coming, the week feels much less overwhelming.
instructions: At the start of each week, write out: (1) What's due this week? (list it all), (2) What day will I do each thing? (assign it), (3) What do I need to prepare in advance? Look at your list each morning and tick things off as you go.
success_criteria: All 3 sections completed. Each due item has an assigned day.

title: The Batch Cluster
prompt: Switching between different types of tasks burns focus. Group similar tasks and do them together.
instructions: Look at your task list for this week. Sort all tasks into clusters by type: ADMIN (emails, forms, calls), CREATIVE (writing, designing, making), THINKING (analysis, planning, reading), ERRANDS (physical tasks, going places). Schedule one block per cluster per day rather than mixing them.
success_criteria: Tasks sorted into at least 3 clusters. At least 2 clusters are assigned to specific time blocks.

title: The Same-Type Stack
prompt: Doing similar things together is faster and less exhausting than jumping between totally different activities.
instructions: Look at your tasks for today. Group any that feel similar: all reading together, all writing together, all physical stuff together. Do one group at a time. Notice: does it feel easier than switching between totally different things?
success_criteria: Tasks grouped into at least 2 types. One group completed without switching away.

title: The If-Then Shield
prompt: Things go wrong. Planning for "wrong" means you don't have to think when it happens.
instructions: Take your plan for tomorrow. Ask: "What is the most likely thing that could disrupt this?" Write it down. Now write: "If [disruption] happens, then I will [specific action]." Create 2-3 If-Then pairs. These are your shields. When disruption hits, you already know what to do.
success_criteria: 2-3 written If-Then pairs for tomorrow's plan. Each "then" action is specific enough to act on without thinking.

title: The Plan B Pocket
prompt: Every good plan has a backup. What's yours?
instructions: Think of one task or plan you have this week. Ask: "What could go wrong?" Pick the most likely problem. Now write your Plan B — what will you do if that problem happens? Keep it simple. One problem, one backup.
success_criteria: One likely problem identified and one specific Plan B written.

title: The End-of-Task Debrief
prompt: Every completed task is a free lesson in how you work. Most people skip this lesson.
instructions: Immediately after finishing any significant task, spend 5 minutes answering: (1) What part of my plan worked well? (2) What slowed me down or went differently than expected? (3) What would I do differently next time? Keep these in a running "lessons" document.
success_criteria: All 3 debrief questions answered in writing. Notes added to a running lessons document.

title: The How Did That Go? Check
prompt: Finishing a task is great. Understanding HOW you did it makes you better next time.
instructions: After finishing a piece of homework, a chore, or a project, answer these 3 questions: (1) Did I stick to my plan? (2) What took longer than I expected? (3) What would make it easier next time? Write the answers — even one sentence each.
success_criteria: 3 questions answered. At least one specific insight written about what to do differently.
